titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Judith Braun Papers MSS.530
titlestmt.author: Kate Fisher

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-11-30 10:53:27 -0500.

physdesc.extent: in 4 record cartons, 1 manuscript box, and 2 oversize flat boxes.

did.abstract: The Judith Braun Papers consist of records of artist Judith Braun's creative feminist work from 1987 to 2014. Artwork, research, correspondence, and articles pertaining to her exhibitions from 1978 to 1997 create the bulk of this collection. After graduating from Empire State College in Albany, New York in 1979 with a Bachelor's Degree in Fine Arts, Braun pursued realistic figure painting until 1982 when she transitioned to combining her visual artwork with text and innuendo through photocopying. The artwork within this collection reflects Braun's changing artistic output and her creation of the persona Weinperson. Applications for grants, residencies, and show proposals from 1987 to 2011 are included as a part of this collection as well as a small amount of interviews from 2012 to 2014. The posters available in this collection are remnants of Braun's large scale photocopying process.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Judith Braun Papers consist of records of artist Judith Braun's creative work from 1987 to 2014. Artwork, research, correspondence, and articles pertaining to exhibitions of her work from 1978 to 1997 create the bulk of this collection. The collection also contains applications for grants, residencies, and show proposals from 1987 to 2011, as well as interviews with Braun from 2012 to 2014. Of particular significance to the trajectory of Braun's artistic career are the collection of tarot card readings from 1998 to 2001, which inspired her to re-enter the art world in 2001. The collection documents Braun's large scale photocopying process with initial images, enlarged photocopied grid pieces, photographs and slides of large scale wall hangings, and large scale posters.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Judith Braun (1947 - ), also known as Judith Weinperson and Weinperson, is a New York City-based artist. After graduating from Empire State College in Albany, New York, in 1979 with a Bachelor's Degree in Fine Arts, she pursued realistic figure painting until 1982 when she transitioned to combining her visual artwork with text and innuendo through photocopying. During this artistic transition Braun was pursuing her Masters in Arts and Masters in Fine Arts at State University of New York at Albany, New York, graduating in 1983. In 1989 she created the persona Weinperson, an alteration of her married name Weinman. The Weinperson persona represented Braun in her experiments with racial and sexual innuendos in her photocopied creations. Braun exhibited as Weinperson or Judith Weinperson from 1988 to 1995 before retreating from her creative practice until 2003.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Judith Braun was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Judith Braun Papers; MSS 530; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, the collection was arranged into series based on the original order and topical arrangement of the records created and maintained by Judith Braun, and original folder titles were retained.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor Judith Braun. The donor arrangement has ten series without subseries. These series were labeled by the artist to aid her artistic process. The series arrangement is:

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Judith Braun, 2017. The accession number associated with this gift is 2018.029.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Proposals - Correspondence - Shows series contains correspondence between Braun and organizations interested in her artwork and dates between 1987 to 2014. These organizations include jurored shows; non-profit galleries such as White Columns in New York, New York; and art institutions including The New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York, New York and Kunstlerhaus Bethanien in Berlin, Germany.

did.unittitle: Columbia - SIX GOOD CASES FOR MANSLAUGHTER
LIST Kathy Holbreidt + Dana Friis Hausen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Articles - Reading series includes clippings collected by Braun from 1978 to 1997 that influenced her artwork on racial and sexual innuendo. Publications include The Village Voice, The New York Times, and The New Yorker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Applications series contains correspondence between Braun and organizations providing grant and residencies, dating between 1988 and 2003.

did.unittitle: New York Foundation for the Arts Grants 1988 - 89 painting sculpture
New York Foundation for the Arts - OCT. 92 94
New York Foundation for the Arts Video 2003

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Artwork series is a record of Braun's creative process producing her 152 week serial art piece ANNOUNCEMENT and her colossal photocopied wall art. The photocopied images in this series are the the inspiration for her innuendo artwork in between 1992 and 1994.

did.unittitle: READ MY PUSSY - Rag Paper Blue/Blk.
red mi poose - White Columns Piece
READ MY PUSSY - Small Mouth Grid Edition
READ MY PUSSY - Small Diag. Edition
Paintings - Single Standard MEEK FEET Restoration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Early Brochures series consists of pamphlets from Braun's exhibitions from 1980 to 1992 in both solo and group shows.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Notebooks series contains notebooks describing Braun's compositions from 1978 to 1994. Included in this series are clippings collected by Braun to influence her artwork on racial and sexual innuendo as well as slides of her work from 1978 to 1994. Braun's handwritten notebooks contain few sketches and are filled with lists and art production goals. These notebooks document the art creation of a year or are dedicated to a specific art piece.

did.unittitle: Empire State College 1ST Contract - Bill Frankonis Readings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Newspaper Clippings series contains articles taken from publications, from 1978 to 1994, such as The Village Voice, The New York Times, and The New Yorker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Weinperson series consists of a numerical series of photocopied postcards and production material for the art piece ANNOUNCEMENT. This material dates from 1993 to 2001 and was created by Braun using her Weinperson persona exploring her visual interpretations of racial and sexual innuendo. The finished product of 152 post cards are arranged together at the beginning of the series and then the preparation for each week's art piece is collected in numbered folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Tarot series consists of tarot card readings and information on tarot interpretation, dating from 1998 to 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Posters series contains gridwork that was integral to Braun's colossal wall art photocopying process. This art process material is from her exhibitions in between 1990 and 1995. This collection contains gridwork posters from her exhibitions at Sonyun Yi Gallery in New York from 1990; the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa, Alabama from 1991; On The Wall Gallery in New York from 1990; Columbia University in New York from 1991; the Drawing Center in New York from 1990; the Künstlerhaus Bethanien in Berlin, Germany from 1992; and the New Museum for Contemporary Art in New York in 1994.
